CARDINAL . According to LAW , section CARDINAL , of LAW ( rikoslaki , strafflagen ; as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ,
" [ ORG addition to what is provided above in LAW , grounds mitigating the punishment that are also to be taken into consideration are ;

( CARDINAL ) a considerably long period that has passed since the commission of the offence ; if the punishment that accords with established practice would for these reason lead to an unreasonable or exceptionally detrimental result . "

CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE ( GPE ) ORG noted that , although there were no legal provisions justifying the dismissal of a criminal charge due to unreasonably lengthy proceedings , such a dismissal or declaring a case inadmissible might in some exceptional circumstances , for example if their duration ruled out a good defence , be the only effective remedy satisfying the requirements of LAW . That was , however , not the case in that precedent case . In considering whether there were grounds for applying LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW , ORG held that it had to be decided in PERSON whether the duration of the proceedings ( in the precedent case DATE ) had been unreasonable . It concluded that in this case there were no grounds to waive a sentence or to mitigate the sentence owing to the duration of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . In its judgment of DATE ( PERSON ) , ORG , applying LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW , reduced the sentence imposed upon the applicant by DATE owing to the length of the proceedings that had lasted DATE . The court imposed an immediate term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , finding that it was not justifiable to mitigate the sentence further by suspending the term of imprisonment .

CARDINAL . A new LAW has been added to LAW ( oikeudenkäymiskaari , rättegångsbalken ; as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) which entered into force on DATE . This LAW provides for a possibility to accelerate pending proceedings if there are specific reasons for so doing , inter aliaAny application for acceleration must be addressed to ORG before which the case is pending and shall be examined by a single judge formation . A case which has been granted priority must be examined by ORG without delay and before any other cases . The decision to grant or refuse priority can not be separately appealed .

CARDINAL . The Act on Compensation for Excessive Duration of Judicial Proceedings ( laki oikeudenkäynnin viivästymisen hyvittämisestä , lagen om gottgörelse för dröjsmål vid rättegång ; Act no . ORG ) entered into force on DATE . The LAW provides for a party a right to receive compensation from ORG funds whenever judicial proceedings concerning that party have been excessively long .
CARDINAL . As to its scope of application , section CARDINAL of the LAW provides as follows :
“ This Act is applicable by general courts to litigious , non - contentious and criminal actions .

Reduction of a penal sanction on the basis of excessive length of judicial proceedings is provided for in LAW ( CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . Irrespective of this LAW , compensation for damage caused by excessive duration of judicial proceedings can be obtained as provided in LAW ( CARDINAL ) . ”
CARDINAL . The right to compensation is set out in section CARDINAL of the LAW which provides the following :

“ A private party is entitled to receive a reasonable amount of compensation as referred to in section CARDINAL from the ORG funds if judicial proceedings last an excessively long time resulting in a violation of the party ’s right to a trial within a reasonable time . ”

CARDINAL . When evaluating the length of the proceedings , in addition to the length itself , the nature and scope of the subject - matter , the actions of the parties , authorities and courts in respect of the proceedings as well as the importance of the subject - matter to a party are to be taken into consideration pursuant to section CARDINAL of the LAW . Moreover , the case - law under LAW is also to be taken into account .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL of the LAW , the period to be taken into account starts in civil and non - contentious civil matters when action is initiated before a court ; in criminal matters when the competent authority has notified the defendant of a crime suspected to have been committed by him or when a crime suspicion directed at him has had an essential bearing on his position ; or when a claim made by a party has become pending before a court .
CARDINAL . As to the amount of compensation , section CARDINAL of the LAW provides the following :
“ The purpose of compensation is to compensate for the anxiety , uncertainty or other comparable harm caused to a party by excessive duration of proceedings .

The amount of compensation is QUANTITY per year for DATE that the proceedings have been delayed for reasons attributable to the ORG . The total amount of compensation shall be increased by a maximum of CARDINAL if the merits are particularly important to the party . A matter shall be considered particularly important if it has a direct bearing on the person ’s health , income , legal position or some other comparable consideration . The compensation may be reduced or increased on the basis of a consideration referred to section CARDINAL or for some other comparable consideration .
The compensation amount shall not exceed MONEY . This maximum amount of compensation may be exceeded in special circumstances .

There is no entitlement to monetary compensation as far as a sanction imposed has been mitigated due to the excessive duration of proceedings . If compensation has been awarded earlier by a final decision in the same matter , it shall be taken into account as a reduction when determining the new compensation . ”
CARDINAL . As to the procedure for claiming compensation , section CARDINAL of the LAW provides as follows :

“ A claim for compensation shall be lodged with the general court in charge of the case before the consideration of the merits is closed under the pain of loss of the right of action . Such a claim can not be lodged as late as at ORG stage without a valid reason .
A claim may be made in writing or orally . Justifications for the claim shall be presented . ”

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL of the LAW , the public prosecutor shall use in criminal matters the right of action on behalf of the ORG in respect of a compensation matter while ORG shall use it in respect of other matters . ORG shall not be provided with an opportunity to be heard in respect of the compensation claim unless there is a special reason for this .

CARDINAL . As to the decision - making , section CARDINAL of the LAW provides that the court shall decide on the compensation claim when it decides on the merits of a case . The composition competent for deciding on the merits shall also be competent for deciding on the issue of compensation . The court must notify ORG of the decision on compensation without delay .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Act concerns costs . It provides as follows :

“ If a party is awarded compensation , reimbursement of the necessary and reasonable costs incurred by him for claiming compensation shall be ordered to be paid to him from ORG funds unless otherwise reimbursed from ORG funds . No fee is charged for the processing of the compensation claim . ”

CARDINAL . According to LAW , a decision rendered by a court on the compensation claim can be appealed against in the same manner as the decision on the merits . ORG can appeal against the ORG decision without having to register its intent to appeal .

CARDINAL . As concerns the payment of compensation , section CARDINAL of the LAW provides that the compensation shall be paid to a party within DATE on which the compensation decision became final . The compensation shall be paid by ORG . A prohibition on attaching the compensation and its tax - fee nature is provided for by a separate provision .

CARDINAL . The Act has already been applied by the domestic courts . In its judgment of DATE ORG rejected a compensation complaint as it had been filed too late . On DATE ORG found in a case that proceedings had been too lengthy when they had lasted DATE and DATE at CARDINAL levels of jurisdiction , and awarded the applicants QUANTITY respectively .
